Finnish Design Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, 18 West 86th Street; (212) 501-3000.

''Finnish Modern Design: Utopian Ideals and Everyday Realities, 1930-1997,'' an exhibition of 144 objects, photographs and drawings about the origins and history of the Modernist design movement in Finland, opens today and runs through June 30. The exhibition, organized by the Bard center and the Museum of Art and Design, Helsinki, will include furniture, ceramics, fashions, glass objects, jewelry, textiles, lighting fixtures, graphics and metal objects.
Open Tuesday through Sunday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays to 8 P.M.. Admission is $2; those 65 and older, $1; children under 12, no charge.
Shining Silks Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street; (212) 879-5500.

''When Silk Was Gold: Central Asian and Chinese Textiles in the Metropolitan and Cleveland Museums of Art,'' an exhibition of more than 65 examples of silk tapestries, embroidered textiles, clothing and woven cloths, starts on Tuesday and continues through May 17. The textiles were made from the 8th to 15th centuries, when silk textiles were used as currency and for imperial gifts and tributes, in addition to being traded commercially. Open Tuesday through Sunday, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M.; Friday and Saturday until 9 P.M. Suggested admission is $8; students and those 65 and older, $4.
Architecture Talks Municipal Art Society, Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 935-3960.

Representatives from six architectural firms who have completed plans for the renovation of Columbus Circle will give an illustrated lecture on Wednesday at 6 P.M. about their ideas for redesigning the plaza. Reservations required. No charge.
